summary: Bettas come in a huge variety of colors, patterns, and shapes. They are probably one of the most commonly kept fish ever. Male bettas should never be housed together as they will fight. Female bettas may, in some cases, be kept together depending on the temperament of the individual fish and the size of the tank.
Mollys are a fairly hardy livebearer that are good for beginners. They are affordable, easy to feed and easy to breed.

Clown Killifish are a small yellow and black striped fish with a spade-shaped tail fin. On males, this fin is red and gives the fish their other name, Rocket Killifish. The males might not get along, so it's advised to put multiple females per male and provide plenty of hiding spaces. Killifish are known for jumping out of tanks, so it is strongly advised to have a lid or a very thick layer of floating plants.

Otocinclus, also known as dwarf suckers or oto cats, are a very small algae-eating fish. Because they are wild-caught, they have a reputation for not knowing how to eat in captivity and starving off. These fish should only be added to established tanks with plenty of soft algae for them to eat. In the wild, these fish swim in large shoals of several hundred fish, so it is strongly advised to keep at least 6 or more if your tank produces enough algae to support them. These fish are very hard to breed in captivity. There are actually a few different types of Oto that your LFS might stock, these include Otocinclus affins, Otocinclus macrospilus, Otocinclus cocama and more. These different types of Otos have slight size variations, as well as different patterning, however they should all shoal together regardless.

Cherry Barbs are known to be one of the most peaceful species of barbs. The males will have a brilliant red color under the right conditions, and they will make a big display of chasing females around. Females are a golden-brown color with a dark lateral stripe.

The Siamese Algae Eater is a very active algae-eating fish. These fish will eat most types of algae, and some will even eat black beard algae. Other fish can be easily confused for and sold as SAEs, including the Flying Fox. These fish will appreciate each other's company if your aquarium will allow for multiple.

The Cardinal Tetra will grow a bit larger than the standard neon tetra. Cardinal Tetras have a much larger area of red coloring than neon tetras. These fish are very popular for their vibrant colors and peaceful nature. Tetras like to swim long distances, so the footprint of the tank may be more imporant than the number of gallons.

The Neon Tetra is one of the most commonly-kept fish in the hobby. There are many similar species of tetra, such as the green neon tetra, cardinal tetra, diamondhead tetra, black neon tetra, and many more. Tetras like to swim long distances, so the footprint of the tank may be more imporant than the number of gallons.

Green Neon Tetras are smaller than standard Neon Tetras. Although they are smaller, this does not mean they are more suited for beginners. Green Neon Tetras will do best with a lower PH and a blackwater environment. These tetras have less red than the standard Neon Tetras, and their blue stripe will range between royal-blue and turquoise, depending on lighting and viewing angle. Tetras like to swim long distances, so the footprint of the tank may be more imporant than the number of gallons.

Freshwater Angel Fish are very popular in the fishkeeping hobby. They're a palm-sized saucer with long, beaurtiful fins. Angel Fish come in many different patterns and colors, including black, silver, white, and orange. They are typically peaceful but may become territorial when breeding. Keep their long flowing fins and their relatively large size in mind when choosing tank mates: any fish who are known to nip long fins or who can fit in an Angel's mouth will not be a good choice.

Endler's Livebearers are actually very similar to the common guppy, however they are very distinct in appearance with their bold colors and patterning. Endler's often have a color-blocking pattern like you might find on an 80's jacket. Don't let their flashy looks fool you though, Endler's are hardy and easy to keep and breed.

The Chili Rasbora is a red and black nano fish. It is one of the smallest commonly kept freshwater fish. Chili's are a friendly fish which will get along well with many other species. Keep their small size in mind if you are adding them to a community tank by ensuring there are no fish large enough to eat them.

Bala Sharks are a relatively peaceful fish with a shark like dorsal fin. They are known to eat small fish and snails, so keep that in mind when stocking your tank. They are best kept in groups in a tank with plenty of hiding spots and a decent lid as they may jump.

The Zebra Danio is a small striped fish that is very common in the fishkeeping hobby. They are hardy and attractive fish and they come in a few different variations, including the spotted leopard variety, and the long-finned variety. Zebra Danios can be nippy fish, so it is best to avoid fish with long, flowing fins as tank mates, this includes Angels and Bettas.

The Corydoras Catfish, also called the Cory Cat, is a very popular bottom dwelling fish, and for good reason. They are a hardy, peaceful fish which come in many varieties. They make a great clean-up crew as they will happily scavenge through the substrate for uneaten food, detritus worms, and anything else they can find.

The Pygmy Corydoras is a very small and cute species of Cory Catfish. Their care requirements are basically identical, but note that their smaller size may limit suitable tank mates as you do not want to house them with any fish who can eat them.
